fields.description:
One of our environments has this issue when launch instance.
Could you have some idea to debug this issue?
Thanks!

Below is the NC.log

fields.summary: launch instance failed due to error: "curl error: Operation too slow"
fields.environment: Euca 3.2; rhel6u3; one management node, no direct SAN, the walrus use the local disk with LVM, fs is ext4. Instance cache and work are use the local disk with LVM, fs is ext4.

comments.body: We are seeing this on the community cloud. Any workaround for it?
Seen by community user Mike, linking his Q&A post, requested him to share more details about his setup (configuration etc) and logs in this ticket.

I think I missed something.
The netstat result on my last comment is execute in Walrus host.
The result of NC is followed:
netstat -tulpn

Explanation of our eucalyptus components and the hosts' architecture:


The host which host CLC、CC and walrus has two network interface card,named em1 and em2,em1 connect to a router which connect to Internet,the router's ip is 10.68.19.1 and the CLC host's ip is 10.68.19.16.

em2 connect to the NC via a switch which Ip is 129.128.0.1 ,NC's Ip is 129.128.0.20.

The result of issuing "route -n" on CLC host:

[root@localhost ~]# route -n
Kernel IP routing table
Destination     Gateway         Genmask         Flags Metric Ref    Use Iface
192.168.241.192 0.0.0.0         255.255.255.224 U     0      0        0 eucabr1936
129.0.0.0       0.0.0.0         255.0.0.0       U     1      0        0 em2
10.0.0.0        0.0.0.0         255.0.0.0       U     1      0        0 em1
0.0.0.0         10.68.19.1      0.0.0.0         UG    0      0        0 em1

and on NC host:

[root@localhost ~]# route -n
Kernel IP routing table
Destination     Gateway         Genmask         Flags Metric Ref    Use Iface
192.168.0.0     0.0.0.0         255.255.255.0   U     1      0        0 em2
192.168.122.0   0.0.0.0         255.255.255.0   U     0      0        0 virbr0
129.0.0.0       0.0.0.0         255.0.0.0       U     1      0        0 em1
0.0.0.0         129.128.0.1     0.0.0.0         UG    0      0        0 em1

Hi [~starcraftfan] ,

What is the version of Eucalyptus in your setup? Is it 3.2.0 or 3.2.1 ?
Sorry to delay,I see your comment just now,I am using 3.2.0 now!
I am using 3.2.0 and seeing the same thing as of this morning.
Found a workaround for the ECC: a reload of the iptables module on the CC did the trick (this issue is tracked by EUCA-5113).

Does that mean using the following command:

service eucalyptus-cc stop

service iptables stop

service eucalyptus-cc cleanrestart,but it doesn't work.
(it shoud not be cleanstart)Sorry for my typo.

Dear [~starcraftfan]

You need to do this:

service eucalyptus-cc cleanrestart
I see this happening with any new EMI I upload on my 3.2.1 cloud running on top of Fedora 18, I will file a bug in bugzilla also regarding the same , shortly.

I had this issue with Euca 3.2.1 + CentOS. I resolved this issue by 
* increasing walrus.storagemaxtotalcapacity value
* increasing walrus.storagemaxcachesizeinmb value

YMMV!
[~dmitrii] please review in the 3.3 timeframe
It would be great to have a solid recommendation on the workaround here, since ECC is seeing this problem.  Is [~pyara]'s solution the right way to go for now?

I can imagine why bumping up the limits, as [~pyara] did, helped. The curl error is indicative of an open but idle TCP connection from NC to Walrus. Perhaps someone from storage (cc [~neil]) can confirm that Walrus may end up blocking on a connection when some Walrus limit is exceeded? If it's not a known problem, then recreating the conditions in which Walrus limits are exceeded is probably the next best step.

Out of those two options [~pyara] mentions, it's probably more likely to be walrus cache related. Perhaps with sufficient churn (i.e. caching or transfering multiple images simultaneously?) Walrus blocks whilst the cache is occupied with an image which is staging?

I've never trusted the Walrus and his cache. He doesn't let anyone see.
Very interesting, [~agrimm]. Does this mean that increasing {{walrus.storagemaxcachesizeinmb}} will not always work or is this a different solution to the same underlying problem?

I found that [~neil] committed some code into 3.2.2 which may have fixed this issue.  (He wasn't specifically attempting to fix this issue, but the problems he noticed were related.)  The code is here:

https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus/commit/4e63aca17dfe3523fa36a4ce65b70fa6539a27e4

We are no longer seeing the problem on ECC, and I was not able to reproduce on a FastStart 3.2.2 cloud in the limited testing I did.  I'm interested to hear whether other users who have updated to 3.2.2 are still seeing this.  If they are, we should collect some DB queries and listings of their bucket directories.
I suspect this problem has been fixed by [~neil]. I suggest we close the ticket and reopen if it pops up again.
Great, thanks. Do we have a link to a ticket or commit somewhere?
Oh nm, I guess its the one @agrimm has linked?
Approved as release pending per management team review.  Please reopen if there is an issue
Resolved in the 3.3.0 release

[~dmitrii], we need to re-open this as it is not resolved.  There is still a race condition between Walrus caching the image and the NC unable to download the image which results in the same manifested behaviour.
[~lwade] EUCA-6752 has been opened for this.
Redirecting EUCA-6752
